Award.AwardTitle: From Inspiration to Creation - Extraction and Reuse of Shape Characteristics to Support Product Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for the development of a computational technique to allow the identification and reuse of the characteristic shape identities of products from their computer models. The developed algorithms will extract styling information embodied in the geometry and make its elements available for use in future products. This will be accomplished using an identity-preserving hierarchical shape abstraction technique that allows 3D models to be represented with progressively simpler variants involving a suite of base and detail geometries. The identified characteristics will serve as manipulable shape representations comprised of volumes, surfaces, and curves. The algorithm will be implemented and deployed in a geometric design software that allows individual pieces of the deciphered geometries to be assembled, transferred, and blended in innovative ways to facilitate the creation of novel product forms.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to new computer-aided design methods that enable inspirational past designs to inform future designs. The developed techniques will help designers concurrently study large groups of models to reveal historical trends and make future projections. It will also allow companies establish brand identities much more effectively, thereby enhancing style consistency across product families. The shape knowledge computed using the new approach will allow the development of quantitative metrics to measure the strength of analogy between designs. This capability will advance the boundaries of future search algorithms, allowing analogy-based descriptors to facilitate 3D shape retrieval. The outcomes of this award will also enhance design education by allowing experts to better illustrate their thought processes to others, and to quantitatively guide and assess trainees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
- This project created new knowledge and algorithms for shape creation and shape transfer using abstraction and machine learning methods.  The outcomes include novel computational technologies for shape editing and semantic shape manipulation. Also, new methods for learning from procedurally generated data sets to synthesize new 3D models are developed. Finally, the team has demonstrated the core techniques for studying and understanding humans' perception of 3D forms. 


- Primary outcomes: This work has lead to the development of a novel shape manipulation paradigm. A data-driven shape manipulation technique has been developed that allows a computer system to identify the similarities and differences between the models of a product family. From this information, we developed new techniques that allow a constrained deformation space. This space provides a platform in which only logical and admissible deformations are enabled. This work will likely have a significant impact in industries that involve product forms governed by both aesthetic and functional requirements (such as all kinds of transportation vehicles).


- This project developed deign theories and methods for understanding consumers' judgement of products and brand choices using a novel geometric processing technique based on shape abstraction.


- This project developed a new method that enables 3D shapes to be edited and modified using semantic attributes; attributes that humans use in daily life to characterize and describe product qualities. The results have been validated using large scale online human studies. 

- This project also developed a new system for a generative design of structures that are guided by functional descriptors of desired mechanical behaviors. The results have been shown on 3D printed custom parts. 


- The research team plans to augment this technology with additive manufacturing technologies in the immediate future. As such, the 3D printing hardware located within CMU Mechanical Engineering will be utilized to demonstrate the impact of this technology. Specifically, we expect students to take existing designs, deconstruct it to their fundamental elements, and reuse these for the design and fabrication of new products. The additive manufacturing technology will allow students to create very complex forms traditionally impossible to create using conventional technologies.


- All products of this work have been published extensively, and can be found at: http://vdel.me.cmu.edu
